page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: This is an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, mostly in the Parish of Aldbourne which extends west and north of the area. The village occupies about one twelth of the area where two dry valleys join to form the perennial Ald brook, flowing south to the Kennet. In the south east the height is about 400m rising to nearly 700m towards Upham at the opposite corner. Most of the area outside the village is farmed producing barley and sheep, with some dairying and stock. Hedges and trees mark the clays to the south, but the chalk downs to the north have been virtually treeless from Prehistoric times. Farming employs few people and much machinery, so that many have to find employment in the modern industries and offices in Swindon. There is still a wide range of services and shops in the village
